titleInfo.title: Perceptions, Predispositions, and Previous Experiences
titleInfo.subTitle: College Students' Attitudes Toward Rhetoric in a Required First Year Composition Course

mods:mods.abstract: "Perceptions, Predispositions, and Previous Experiences: College Students' Attitudes Toward Rhetoric in a Required First-Year Composition Course" explores college composition students' attitudes about the course and key rhetorical concepts in their required college composition course(s) at Florida State University (FSU). The purpose of this study is to highlight students' understanding and knowledge of rhetoric, along with their attitudes toward key concepts, which could inform their performance in class and their ability to use rhetorical concepts in their writing beyond the classroom. Rhetoric is a fundamental concept in many composition courses at the college and university level, but especially prominent at Florida State University. This methodologically qualitative research study used a mixed-methods approach with two focus groups and five follow-up interviews. I conducted this study to observe the predispositions and assumptions students may make about the course and its key concepts in an attempt to comment on how these pre-existing and developing attitudes about rhetoric inform their understanding and even their performance within the context of a required composition class. Whether students explore rhetorical concepts at the high school level or if they are first introduced to them at the university level impacts their perceptions, attitudes, and applications of rhetoric. This study found that students are generally confident writers at the first-year composition level but when asked to define terms, they struggle. Their implied understanding and knowledge is seen through their statements and using these terms and concepts in context. At the very least, some students fail to see connections between this course and future writing while others can note concrete benefits. Ultimately, students' attitudes in the college-composition classroom vary, but they undeniably pull heavily from their previous high school, AP, dual enrollment, Cambridge AICE, and other unknown experiences to make assumptions on rhetoric.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts.
articulation, college composition, first year composition, predispositions, prior knowledge, rhetoric
Michael Neal, Professor Directing Thesis; Elias Dominguez Barajas, Committee Member; Rhea Estelle Lathan, Committee Member.
